(d) GOGAT (glutamine:2-oxoglutarate aminotransferase): glutamine + 2-oxoglutarate + 2 Fd(red) → 2 glutamate + 2 Fd(ox). Regenerates glutamate for the GS reaction and produces net glutamate. (2) GS/GOGAT cycle — together, GS and GOGAT form a cycle: NH4+ is assimilated by GS into glutamine, then one amino group is transferred to 2-oxoglutarate by GOGAT to produce two glutamate molecules — one is recycled for GS, the other provides amino groups for transamination to other amino acids. (3) Transport forms — glutamine is the primary organic nitrogen transport form because it has two nitrogen atoms per molecule (high N:C ratio) and is chemically stable. Asparagine (also 2N per molecule) is the next most abundant. These amino acids are loaded into the xylem in roots and transported to shoots in the transpiration stream. (4) Site of assimilation — varies by species. In many herbaceous plants and crops, much NO3- assimilation occurs in roots before export. In some species (especially trees), NO3- may be transported to leaves for assimilation. The experimental finding of glutamine as the primary labeled form in shoots confirms root assimilation followed by transport. Direct vacuolar storage (A), inorganic transport only (B), and bacterial fixation (D) do not explain the amino acid labeling pattern.

questions.question: Carnivorous plants like Nepenthes (tropical pitcher plants) trap and digest insects primarily to supplement their nutrition with:
options: Carbon, because they cannot photosynthesize
Water, because they grow in arid deserts

Nitrogen (and phosphorus) — carnivorous plants are typically autotrophic (photosynthetic) and grow in nutrient-poor habitats (acidic bogs, peat swamps, nutrient-leached tropical soils); insect digestion provides supplemental nitrogen and phosphorus that are scarce in these substrates, while carbon is obtained through normal photosynthesis
Oxygen, because their roots are permanently submerged
questions.explanation: Carnivorous plants are among the most fascinating examples of nutritional adaptation in plants: (1) Photosynthetic autotrophs — all carnivorous plants are photosynthetic. They produce their own carbohydrates through normal C3 photosynthesis. Carnivory does NOT replace photosynthesis — it supplements mineral nutrition. (2) Nutrient-poor habitats — carnivorous plants typically grow in habitats with extremely low mineral nutrient availability: acidic sphagnum bogs, peat swamps, white sand savannas, tepuis (table-top mountains in Venezuela), and nutrient-leached tropical soils. In these habitats, nitrogen and phosphorus are the most limiting nutrients. (3) Nutritional benefit — insect digestion provides: (a) Nitrogen: proteins in insect bodies are broken down to amino acids by digestive enzymes (proteases, esterases) secreted into the pitcher fluid or on glandular surfaces. Nitrogen absorption can account for 10-80% of total plant nitrogen depending on prey capture rate. (b) Phosphorus: from insect exoskeletons (chitin contains P) and internal tissues. (c) Other minerals: K, Ca, Mg, Fe from prey tissues. (4) Digestive mechanisms — vary by genus: (a) Nepenthes/Sarracenia (pitchers): modified leaves forming fluid-filled pitfalls; digestive glands secrete proteases, esterases, ribonucleases. (b) Drosera (sundews): glandular trichomes produce sticky mucilage and digestive enzymes; leaves curl around trapped prey. (c) Dionaea (Venus flytrap): snap-trap mechanism with trigger hairs; digestive glands on inner trap surface. (d) Utricularia (bladderworts): aquatic suction traps that capture microorganisms in <1 ms. (5) Cost of carnivory — modified leaves for trapping have reduced photosynthetic area, creating a cost-benefit trade-off. Carnivory is advantageous only in nutrient-poor, high-light habitats where the nitrogen gain from prey exceeds the photosynthetic cost of maintaining traps. They are not non-photosynthetic (A), they grow in wet habitats (B is wrong), and oxygen acquisition (D) is not the primary purpose.

questions.question: A researcher suspects that a newly discovered Arabidopsis mutant has impaired aquaporin function in root cell membranes. To test this, the most informative experiment would be to:
options: Measure leaf color to assess chlorophyll content
Count the number of root hairs per centimeter of root length

Measure root hydraulic conductivity (Lp) using a root pressure probe or osmotic step-change experiment — compare Lp in the mutant vs. wild type, and also treat wild-type roots with HgCl2 (a known aquaporin inhibitor); if the mutant has impaired aquaporins, its Lp should be significantly reduced compared to wild type, and should be similar to HgCl2-treated wild type
Analyze seed germination rate in the mutant vs. wild type
questions.explanation: Testing aquaporin function requires measuring membrane water permeability: (1) Root hydraulic conductivity — Lp (hydraulic conductivity) is a measure of how easily water flows through root tissues. It reflects the collective water permeability of all membranes in the radial pathway from soil to xylem. Since aquaporins provide the major pathway for transmembrane water flow, reduced aquaporin function should directly reduce Lp. (2) Measurement methods — (a) Root pressure probe: a microcapillary attached to a pressure transducer is sealed to the cut end of a detopped root system. Applied pressure changes or osmotic step-changes in the bathing solution cause water flow, and Lp is calculated from the flow rate and driving force. (b) Osmotic step-change: transferring roots from one solution to another with different osmolarity causes a rapid volume change (measured by flow into/out of the root). The rate of this response is proportional to Lp. (c) High-pressure flow meter (HPFM): applies known pressures and measures resulting flow rates. (3) HgCl2 control — mercuric chloride (HgCl2) is a classic aquaporin inhibitor. It binds to cysteine residues near the pore of many aquaporin isoforms, blocking water flow. If the mutant's reduced Lp phenotype is similar to HgCl2-treated wild type, this strongly suggests the mutant's defect is in aquaporin function. Additionally, if HgCl2 has no further effect on the mutant's Lp (already reduced), this confirms that the same pathway is affected. (4) Complementary experiments — reversibility with beta-mercaptoethanol (which reduces Hg-S bonds and restores aquaporin function), molecular characterization of the mutation (which aquaporin gene is affected), and cell-level measurements using stopped-flow spectrophotometry on isolated protoplasts. (5) Leaf color (A), root hair count (B), and germination rate (D) do not directly measure aquaporin function.

questions.question: Sucrose is the primary transport sugar in the phloem of most plant species. The enzyme invertase, which cleaves sucrose into glucose and fructose, plays a critical role in phloem unloading at sink tissues. Cell wall invertase (cwINV) located in the apoplast of sink tissues promotes phloem unloading by:
options: Converting sucrose to starch directly in the sieve tube elements
Transporting sucrose across the plasma membrane of sink cells

Hydrolyzing sucrose in the apoplast to maintain a steep sucrose concentration gradient between the sieve tube (high sucrose) and the apoplast (low sucrose) — this gradient drives continued sucrose efflux from the phloem into the apoplast; the resulting hexoses (glucose and fructose) are then taken up by sink cells via hexose transporters, providing carbon and energy for growth and storage
Blocking phloem sap flow to prevent sugar from leaving the sieve tubes
questions.explanation: Phloem unloading mechanisms at sink tissues are critical for carbon allocation: (1) Apoplastic unloading — in many sink tissues (seeds, fruits, storage organs), sucrose is released from sieve tube elements into the apoplast. Cell wall invertase (cwINV) in the apoplast immediately cleaves arriving sucrose into glucose and fructose. This hydrolysis maintains a low sucrose concentration in the apoplast, keeping the concentration gradient steep between the sieve tube lumen (high sucrose) and the apoplast (low sucrose). This gradient drives continued sucrose efflux from the phloem. (2) Hexose uptake — the glucose and fructose produced by cwINV are taken up by sink cells via monosaccharide transporters (STPs — Sugar Transport Proteins, which are H+/hexose symporters). These hexoses are then metabolized for energy (respiration), growth (cell wall synthesis), or converted to storage forms (starch in amyloplasts, fats in oil bodies). (3) Source of driving force — by continuously removing sucrose from the apoplast (converting it to hexoses), cwINV prevents sucrose from accumulating and equilibrating with the phloem. This maintains the turgor pressure differential between source and sink predicted by the Munch pressure-flow hypothesis. (4) Developmental regulation — cwINV activity is high in rapidly growing and metabolically active sink tissues. It is a major determinant of sink strength. Transgenic plants with increased cwINV in specific sinks show enhanced carbon allocation to those organs. (5) Alternative unloading — symplastic unloading (through plasmodesmata, without membrane crossing) occurs in some sinks (root tips, vegetative storage tissues). In this case, sucrose moves directly from sieve tubes through plasmodesmata into sink cells, where vacuolar or cytoplasmic invertases cleave it. CwINV does not convert sucrose to starch (A), does not transport sucrose (B), and does not block flow (D).
